posts.name: Isaiah Ballestrazze
posts.cooked:
I have recently undertaken the task of creating the first mini Romi swerve bot.

I’m unsure if it’s possible but the goal is to build a smaller version of our current drive train in order to teach some younger members of our team how to program it. We are using YAGSL so I want to use the same library on this bot. 1000000489 1920×1080 264 KB

1000000489 1920×1080 264 KB

1000000489 1920×1080 264 KB

Currently I have run into an issue with the quadrature encoders . On the Romi’s there are assignable pins that you can configure with the Online Web UI. I configured all of them to DIO and created a command in the code that will read the pins and print out a true or false. This worked great and I could see the differences as I slowly turned the motor wheel. However when I went to make an Encoder constructor, and print out a raw encoder.get() value all I got was zeros. If you have any suggestions for me to try it would be highly appreciated! I would put more images but it wont let me.

My Code:

GitHub - IsaiahBallestrazze/Romi2025 Contribute to IsaiahBallestrazze/Romi2025 development by creating an account on GitHub.

Contribute to IsaiahBallestrazze/Romi2025 development by creating an account on GitHub.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: I suspect that you would need to make custom Romi firmware to support more then the 2 encoders.

posts.name: Isaiah Ballestrazze
posts.cooked: I’ve never done anything like that before, is their some guide I could follow? Or a better alternative out their that’s not to bulky?

posts.name: Kyle Swaidner
posts.cooked:
There are a couple of XRP system swerve adaptations out there.  I believe the XRP board supports 4 encoders natively.

posts.name: Isaiah Ballestrazze
posts.cooked: Im just looking at the XRP board, I can use the onboard Motor controllers to control the azimuth motors, then I could use the DIO ports for direction and a PWM for the speed. I just need to figure out how to do digital outputs for the board in wpilib java. I also need to figure out how to use the pwm port directly without the servo class thingy.  I’ll do some more research.

posts.name: Kyle Swaidner
posts.cooked: If you end up buying any I believe there is still a substantial (50%) discount for FRC teams.

posts.name: Martin
posts.cooked: I would love to see this because this is something I have been wanting to do for fun. It can also help teach willing rookies on how to program swerve without giving them a massive full sized robot to do it with.

Great to discover this thread. I am currently embarking on a similar project. As the Romi has only 2 ports for encoders (not viable for project without significant firmware modification on the Arduino-based board), I have acquired this week an XRP kit without frame. We use python, so the code base will be vastly different. Of note, the Romi has an awful built-in gyro even after calibration. I believe that hinders the platform for more advanced projects beyond basic driving. Even if performing auton with any heading-based code, the drift is immense. Self-implemented calibration code can only do so much since, as the unit warms up, the rate of drift shifts and overwhelms the calibration (initial averaging of errors over a set time and offsetting drift). As for the XRP platform, my initial testing is promising. The gyro is rock solid in the x and y axes, with about a 3 degree drift in the Z axis over a 2:30 min period (on my unit at least). I believe swerve movement is possible with only 2 “swerve units” in diagonal opposing positions while using the 2 roller balls as casters for the rest. The frame will need to be custom, of course. With the other 2 motor ports free, they can be used for the 2 drive wheels (with encoders) so now you can have distance-based auton. With a robust gyro, field-centric control will maintain consistency over the 2:30 min game period.
